s.text: There are some neat things here, starting with the novella Q.E.D. , which Stein wrote when she was 29.

The editors, New York University's Catharine Stimpson and independent scholar Harriet Chessman, have done a perfectly fresh job assembling both canonical and neglected pieces to trace the evolution of this oddest of minds.
Also, the angry portrait of Helen shows that, all feminist claims on Stein notwithstanding, she was as capable of misogyny as any man.
Also, the angry portrait of Helen shows that, all feminist claims on Stein notwithstanding, she was as capable of misogyny as any man.
All this exploration makes for some heavy going, and I certainly wouldn't recommend that anyone read these volumes straight through, as I had to for review.

Most of Stein's phases are here: the pioneering "continuous present" tense she invented in Three Lives ; the abstract sketches of friends; the barely performable plays that she compared to landscapes; the difficult holistic theory of literature that made her a surprising star on the American lecture circuit late in life.
Other prolific writers such as Henry James and Mark Twain usually get their stuff sorted into early period and late period and released in dribbles.

Her celebrity image is both frivolous and terrifying: Imagine the souls of Fran Lebowitz and Yogi Berra mingling in a woman who looked like an ancient statue, with a huge, flat face and dark little dots for eyes.
At times, I felt as if I'd inhaled highly caloric food and, just when the sugar coma hit, entered a long line at the department of motor vehicles.
Soon she'd forgotten all about her subjects and begun inquiring into the very nature of composition.
Stein is far more amusing when she forgets her rules and gets drunk on the music of words.
